TAXONOMIC CLASS.content:
TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, frigid Vitrandic
Dystrochrepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Flannery loam, forested, on a 53 percent smooth slope at 3,600 feet elevation. Aspect is southeast.  When described on August 3, 1994, the soil was dry throughout. (Colors are for air dry soil unless otherwise noted)
Oi--1.5 to 1 inch; undecomposed needles, twigs and leaves.
Oe--1 to 0; slightly decomposed needles, twigs and leaves.
A--0 to 2 inches; brown (10YR 4/3) loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; moderate very fine granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; many very fine and common fine roots; many very fine and fine and common medium and few coarse irregular pores; 5 percent fine gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.2); abrupt wavy boundary. (2 to 3 inches thick)
Bw1--2 to 9 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 3/4) moist; weak very fine subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; many very fine and common fine and medium, and few coarse roots; many very fine and common fine and medium irregular pores; 10 percent fine gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.2); clear wavy boundary.
Bw2--9 to 17 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 3/6) moist; weak very fine subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; many very fine, common fine and medium, and few coarse roots; many very fine and few fine and medium irregular pores; 10 percent fine gravel; moderately acid (pH 6.0) clear wavy boundary.  (Combined thickness of the Bw horizons 12 to 18 inches)
2Bw3--17 to 22 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) gravelly sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak very fine and fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine and few fine and medium roots; many very fine and few fine and medium irregular and few very fine tubular pores; 15 percent fine gravel; moderately acid (pH 6.0); abrupt wavy boundary.
2Bw4--22 to 33 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) coarse sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak very fine and fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine and few fine and medium roots; common very fine and fine and few medium irregular and common very fine and fine tubular pores; 10 percent fine gravel; moderately acid (pH 5.6); gradual wavy boundary. (Combined thickness of the 2Bw horizons is 8 to 18 inches thick)
2C1--33 to 46 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) coarse sandy loam, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine and few fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine and common fine and medium irregular and common very fine tubular pores; 5 percent fine gravel; moderately acid (pH 5.6); clear wavy boundary. (9 to 16 inches thick)
2C2--46 to 51 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) loamy coarse sand, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; common very fine amd few fine and medium irregular and few very fine tubular pores; 10 percent fine gravel; strongly acid (pH 5.2); clear wavy boundary. (5 to 13 inches thick)
2Crt--51 inches; very pale brown (10YR 8/4) highly weathered granodiorite, strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist; few very fine and fine roots in fractures; few very fine and fine irregular pores; few faint clay films on highly fractured rock faces and in pores.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Clearwater County Idaho; about 8 miles north and 8 miles east of Headquarters, Idaho; about 2,000 feet north and 200 feet west of the southeast corner of section 1, T.39N., R.6E.; Latitude - 46 degrees, 45 minutes 5 seconds North; Longitude - 115 degrees, 38 minutes, 21 seconds West. USGS Thompson Point Quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to paralithic contact - 40 to 60 inches
Average annual soil temperature - 43 to 46 degrees F.
Soil moisture -  usually moist year round and not dry for 45 or more consecutive days from June to October.
Base saturation - 35 to 60 percent throughout
2BC horizon present in some pedons
Thickness of volcanic ash mantle - 14 to 19 inches
Volcanic glass content in the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction - 5 to 25 percent Acid oxalate extractable Al + 1/2 Fe - 0.45 to 0.70 percent
Phosphate retention - 30 to 45 percent
15 bar water retention on air dried samples - 5 to 10 percent
A horizon
Hue - 7.5YR or 10YR
Value - 2 or 3 moist
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry and 2 or 3 moist
Rock fragments - 3 to 5 percent fine gravel
Reaction - moderately acid to slightly acid
Bulk density - 0.95 - 1.10 g/cc
Bw horizons
Hue - 7.5YR or 10YR
Value - 3 or 4 moist
Chroma - 4 to 6 moist
Rock fragments - 5 to 10 percent gravel
Reaction - moderately acid to slightly acid
Bulk density - 1.05 - 1.35 g/cc
2Bw horizons
Value - 7 or 8 dry and 4 to 6 moist
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry and 4 to 6 moist
Texture - COSL, GR-COSL or GR-SL
Rock fragments - 10 to 25 percent gravel
Reaction - strongly acid to moderately acid
2C horizons
Value - 7 or 8 dry
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry
Texture - COSL, LCOS or GR-LCOS
Rock fragments - 5 to 35 percent gravel
Reaction - strongly acid to moderately acid

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Dullaxe (T) series.  Dullaxe soils are very deep.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Flannery soils are on mountain  slopes at elevations of 2,000 to 4,500 feet with slopes of 35 to 70 percent.  These soils formed in material weathered from granitic or metamorphic rocks with a mixed volcanic ash mantle.  The average annual temperature is 41 to 45 degrees F. and the average annual precipitation is 40 to 50 inches. The frost free season is 70 to 90 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Brodeer (T), Crystalcreek (T), Dullaxe (T) and Jury (T) series.  Brodeer soils have an argillic horizon. Crystalcreek soils are very deep and have an ash mantle that is not mixed. Dullaxe soils are very deep. Jury soils are very deep and have an ash mantle that is not mixed.  All these soils are on mountain slopes.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; rapid runoff; moderate permeability in the upper part and moderately rapid or rapid in the lower part

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for timber production, wildlife habitat and watershed.  Potential natural vegetation is western redcedar, grand fir, Douglas-fir, western larch and western white pine with an understory of queencup beadlily, longtube twinflower, myrtle pachystima, bunchberry dogwood, dampwoods blueberry, western goldthread, common prince's pine, darkwoods violet and common beargrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North central Idaho.  These soils are not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Clearwater County, Idaho, 1995.  The name comes from a local creek.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and other features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - The zone from the mineral soil surface to 2 inches (A horizon)
Volcanic ash cap - The zone from the mineral soil surface to 17 inches (A, Bw1 and Bw2 horizons)
Cambic horizon - The zone from 2 to 33 inches (Bw1, Bw2, 2Bw3 and 2Bw4 horizons)
Particle-size control section - The zone from 10 to 40 inches (Part of the Bw2, the 2Bw3, the 2Bw4 and part of the 2C1 horizons)
The ranges of values listed under the Range In Characteristics for the soil properties Volcanic glass content, Acid-oxalate Al+1/2 Fe, Phosphate retention and 15-bar water retention are estimates only.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
